metadata.titleEn: HiWATER：The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix（automatic meteorological station of No.12)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the automatic weather station (AWS) measurements from site No.12 in the flux observation matrix from 10 May to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.36631° E, 38.86515° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1559.25 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity (HMP45D; 5 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), wind speed and direction (034B; 10 m, towards north), a four-component radiometer (CNR4; 6 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 6 m, vertically downward), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ECh2o-5; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, and -1.0 m), and soil heat flux (HFT3; 3 duplicates with one below the vegetation and the other between plants, 0.06 m). 
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), air pressure (press, hpa), precipitation (rain, mm), wind speed (Ws_10 m, m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m, °), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation; W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IR_2, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2 and Gs_3, W/m^2), soil temperature profile (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, and Ts_100 cm, ℃), and soil moisture profile (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, and Ms_100 cm, %).
           The data processing and quality control steps were as follows. (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min; therefore, there were 144 records per day. The missing data were filled with -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) In this dataset, the time of 0:10 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:10; the data were stored in *.xlsx format. (5) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of how datasets are generated and quality controlled in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: An example of dataset generation and quality control in eco-hydrological research is the process used in the HiWATER project, where observational data are carefully quality controlled through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This ensures the reliability and accuracy of the data, which are made freely available at repositories like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features or parameters are measured in a flux observation matrix used for eco-hydrological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, surface radiation temperature, soil heat flux, multi-layer soil moisture, multi-layer soil temperature

Quantification.Question: How many hierarchical scales of instrumentation were employed to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes during HiWATER?
Quantification.Answer: 1 sparse network, 1 superstation, 4 eddy covariance towers, 4 two-layer automatic meteorological stations

Quantification.Question: How many intensive observation periods and airborne remote sensing missions were conducted during the HiWATER project in 2012?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using a flux observation matrix in eco-hydrological experiments?
Definition.Answer: A flux observation matrix is crucial in eco-hydrological experiments as it helps capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes through a combination of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This setup allows for detailed observation of land-atmosphere interactions across different landscapes, essential for understanding and modeling evapotranspiration and energy fluxes in heterogeneous environments.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies?
Definition.Answer: One major challenge in obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies is the poor availability of data across different spatial and temporal scales. This is compounded by the complexity of setting up and maintaining instrumentation across diverse landscapes, as well as ensuring the quality and consistency of data collected from various sensors and observation networks.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the flux observation matrix compare to those employed in hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing for capturing eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The flux observation matrix utilizes eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations to capture eco-hydrological processes, focusing on ground-based measurements. In contrast, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing employs LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers to obtain data from the air, providing a broader spatial coverage and different dimensional data.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced when estimating evapotranspiration using the TSEB model versus those encountered in multi-scale eco-hydrological observations in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: Estimating evapotranspiration using the TSEB model faces challenges such as the uncertainty in surface–air temperature differences and errors in component temperature due to image classification. In contrast, multi-scale eco-hydrological observations in oasis-desert systems face challenges primarily from the lack of multiscale data availability, which limits the understanding and upscaling of eco-hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multi-scale and multidisciplinary data improve the estimation of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multi-scale and multidisciplinary data can enhance the estimation of evapotranspiration by capturing the complex interactions between soil and vegetation in heterogeneous landscapes. HiWATER addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by using hierarchically nested scales to obtain diverse data, which allows for better modeling of eco-hydrological processes and evapotranspiration over varied land surfaces.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using thermal infrared cameras for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures in agricultural areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential challenges include image classification errors, which can vary with vegetation abundance, leading to misclassification of soil and canopy pixels. This may cause overestimation of canopy temperature under developing vegetation. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could result in uncertainties in estimated temperatures, affecting the accuracy of component temperature calculations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to measure evapotranspiration components such as evaporation and transpiration separately on the ground in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty is primarily due to the limited effectiveness of current composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions. Errors in image classification can lead to soil pixels being misclassified as vegetation pixels, causing an overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as the short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, contribute to the measurement challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective behind collecting multi-scale eco-hydrological data using hierarchically nested instrumentation in an oasis-desert area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes alongside eddy covariance measurements in validating evapotranspiration models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation is to achieve better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates by using isotopes to provide a more reliable comparison with model predictions and eddy covariance measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring data quality control for a multiscale eco-hydrological dataset in an oasis-desert area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All observational data are carefully quality controlled through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. This involves using a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index, alongside hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technologies enable the effective collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The effective collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes is enabled by the use of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, which include EC towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers are utilized to capture data across various spatial scales.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in thermal infrared imaging technologies enable more precise separation of soil and canopy component temperatures in evapotranspiration models?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in thermal infrared imaging technologies, such as the use of a high-precision thermal infrared camera, enable more precise separation of soil and canopy component temperatures by providing accurate radiometric temperature measurements. These measurements are crucial for estimating the soil and canopy component temperatures, which are then used in models like the TSEB for improved estimations of evapotranspiration components.

Enablement.Question: What methodological approaches enable the partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: Methodological approaches that enable the partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in agricultural areas include using the TSEB model in combination with stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance measurements. The separation is further enhanced by accurately calculating soil and canopy component temperatures from thermal camera images, which allows for precise estimation of the component fluxes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using existing data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is particularly challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy. The uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference is dominant due to errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures. Additionally, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in arid regions, with errors caused by image classification errors and atmospheric conditions.

Expectation.Question: What factors could limit the effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: The effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions is limited by errors in image classification, which vary with vegetation abundance. Soil pixels are sometimes misclassified as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimation of canopy temperature. This is compounded by ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, which can introduce uncertainties in estimated temperatures. Additionally, uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy can further affect accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you consider the multiscale data collection approach in capturing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: The multiscale data collection approach is quite effective as it involves instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, allowing for comprehensive capture of eco-hydrological processes. This method addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by employing a combination of ground-based measurements, remote sensing, and a network of sensors to collect diverse and detailed data.

Judgmental.Question: What are your views on the challenges associated with using composite temperature separation methods for evapotranspiration estimation in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges with composite temperature separation methods in arid regions are significant, primarily due to the classification errors in image processing, which affect the accuracy of soil and canopy temperature estimates. These errors can lead to overestimations or uncertainties in the model's performance, particularly under conditions of vegetation abundance or strong atmospheric advection. Addressing these inaccuracies is crucial for improving model reliability.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multi-scale observations are effectively conducted in a heterogeneous landscape for eco-hydrological studies.
Assertion.Answer: In the HiWATER experiment, multi-scale observations are conducted using hierarchically nested scales to capture eco-hydrological processes. This includes the use of a flux observation matrix with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as airborne remote sensing missions with LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting data on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges in collecting data on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces is the limited availability of multiscale observations. Additionally, the accuracy of models like the TSEB model can be affected by uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences and the classification errors in image pixels when separating soil and vegetation components.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in measuring and validating evapotranspiration components using remote sensing and ground-based observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in measuring and validating evapotranspiration components include the difficulty in separating soil and canopy temperatures due to image classification errors, particularly in arid regions. Errors in temperature derivation can result from misclassification of vegetation abundance and ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation. Additionally, the accuracy of latent heat flux estimations is affected by uncertainties in both the TSEB model and the EC system. Strong advective conditions in irrigated agricultural areas further complicate accurate measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential for integrating high-resolution thermal imaging with traditional meteorological measurements to improve evapotranspiration estimation models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Integrating high-resolution thermal imaging with traditional meteorological measurements, such as those from a boundary layer tower, can enhance evapotranspiration estimation models. The use of thermal infrared cameras allows for the precise measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are critical inputs for the TSEB model. This integration enables a more accurate separation of soil and vegetation latent fluxes, improving the reliability of E/ET% and T/ET% estimations under various vegetation types and climatic conditions.
